item.description: Wordle 265 6/6 ‚¨ú‚¨ú‚¨ú‚¨ú‚¨ú üü®‚¨ú‚¨úüü®‚¨ú üü®üü©‚¨ú‚¨ú‚¨ú ‚¨úüü©üü©üü©üü© ‚¨úüü©üü©üü©üü© üü©üü©üü©üü©üü© whew
Twitter unveils version of site that can bypass Russia block. https://t.co/mNwOm6rLju
@GuySie I don‚Äôt think you understood what I was saying
50 Photos That Prove the '70s Was the Decade With the Best Style. https://t.co/7KoTCkB1Ji
Brian Eno Creates a List of 20 Books That Could Rebuild Civilization. https://t.co/ZJ0uSEaHI8

It‚Äôs kind of funny that Amazon, where we spend actual dollars doesn‚Äôt have two factor login but the sites where we don‚Äôt spend any money like Twitter require us to go through a dance were they send a code to a phone ignoring the fact that phones are very easily hijacked.

1/3 Something that keeps repeating on the news, they‚Äôre interviewing someone from Ukraine who makes a plea for help, and the interviewer, all they can say is I hope you stay safe. an awkward moment.
2/3 But I think it reveals that our journalism has a script that it can‚Äôt deviate from. Like Russia, we have oligarchs. And they control the news we hear. in this case the way that works is exposed. We only get a certain kind of news.
3/3 Our journalism isn‚Äôt a place where ideas are discussed and different opinions are heard. It‚Äôs pretty much just entertainment. We only hear with the oligarchs want us to hear.
It‚Äôs appalling that Russia, unable to defeat the Ukraine military (a much smaller country btw) attacks and starves undefended children, mothers, older people.
You Don‚Äôt Really Ever Own an EV. https://t.co/ZpLUQjynQ0
James Worthy blasts Lakers for quitting, Carmelo Anthony responds. https://t.co/cuXGSslpdS
2020 Census Undercounted Hispanic, Black and Native American Residents. https://t.co/h3D33RGzRx
Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen says inflation could be high for a year. https://t.co/pjCuY76z5y
Off The Easel. (This appears to be the software that's running the art accounts I love.) https://t.co/DgrxSb4swL
@jeffjarvis @benedictevans kind of proves there was a business model for news in the age of the internet.
The Invention of the Index. https://t.co/eddQmCQZ0H
MLB reaches agreement with players, ending months-long lockout. https://t.co/qre0nmb5Wz
@brooke @CaseyNewton no not at all. i just don't like having my time wasted like that, as i said.
@CaseyNewton my time isn't free either casey. hopefully i'll never waste any time with your writing in the future, i'll try to remember that. no need to reply.
@tanyaweiman I do. When the power goes out I really feel it. ;-)
@jeffjarvis Amen. I think that should be in the Constitution. Sort of the inverse of the First Amendment. No one should be forced to support speech they find unsupportable.

1/7 I think if I were designing an RSS reader app now, I would first do a reader that only worked with content written in my own blogging tool. That way I could really drill in there, sharpen the edges, create an ideal user experience for both writers and readers. I would not try
2/7 to support everything that's out there. Anyway, once that was working well, I'd try to add feeds with the help of people who write on other sites, and hopefully they can tweak up their feeds so they work really well in my reader. Ideally I'd have good communication with the
3/7 devs who work on their blogging software. But writers and readers drive the process, ideally ones with experience with user testing software. All the while I'd publish my notes so other designers could emulate them. See, the thing is: RSS is supposed to be a standard, but in
4/7 the early days there was a free-for-all wild west mentality that meant no one worked with anyone else because they were all hell-bent on world domination. The idea was I don't need you because I own this shit. Well you can't all own it. That made a mess of things. Now it's
5/7 almost 20 years later, and it should be obvious that hurrying up isn't the answer. We can create another mess, or we can slowly rebuild and create a strong, well-understood standard, and forget about world domination, let's just make a nice reading and writing environment.
6/7 Software is an art, not just a way to get rich. That would be what I would focus on. I have a motto "Slow down to hurry up." Think about the 15 wasted years in RSS-land, and you'll see what I mean. And btw, this would not be an invitation to have another fight with RDF nerds.
7/7 It would be about writers and readers not nerds. Sorry.
@eliehonig I think there's a simple explanation -- Garland doesn't want to be a hero like Zelensky.
I live two hours north of NYC but I haven't been there since the summer of 2019. Just thought that was worth mentioning.

@CaseyNewton -- i was reading your article about substack and just when it got interesting, i had to sign up for something i have no interest in signing up for. i would love to know what you think about rss etc, but i'm not going to take the jump and subscribe.

Substack‚Äôs Google Reader‚Äìesque app is part of ‚Äúmedia ecosystem based on different laws of physics,‚Äù company says. https://t.co/LKrjescxbO
Comments on the possible new developing RSS/blogging ecosystem.
https://t.co/yiXXPuIXDd https://t.co/9r5FH2b6zz
This is how Substack deals with title-less posts.
Permit me to comment as the Dean Emeritus of the RSS School of Reader Design (a title I just made up). https://t.co/xMZUpPZI2b
1. This post does not have a title. You have given prominence to a bit of nonsense, the permalink to the post. The reader doesn't care what the permalink is, they just want to click on an icon and be taken there.
2. Why do you include the description of the site before the text of the post? It certainly isn't where the site description belongs from a writer/reader point of view.
3. Why doesn't the More.. link simply expand the rest of the post. The feed includes the full text. Why make the reader go offsite to read it?
